title: Charlestown Azzurri withdraw from NPLW Northern NSW reserve grade | Camden Haven Courier
body_text:
Back-to-back defending NPLW Northern NSW champions Charlestown Azzurri will not field a reserve-grade side this year.
Subscribe now for unlimited access.
or signup to continue reading
Azzurri collected every piece of Northern NSW Football (NNSWF) women's silverware last year but have been unable to complete a senior squad following a mass exodus of players.
The club will be allowed to field just a first-grade side in 2026 but must also have a reserve-grade team in 2027 to retain their NPLW licence.
While disappointed with the outcome, Charlestown vice-president Roby Valentinis was confident Azzurri's NPLW program would be back to full strength next year.
"We are obviously disappointed because we know the numbers are out there, but they just haven't come across to the club," Valentinis told the Newcastle Herald on Monday.
"We've been informed that other clubs have got way too many players, but they just haven't made their decisions yet.
"So, the real disappointment is that there's a fear of girls actually missing out on playing at all."
NPLW is a seven-club competition and already has a bye each round.
What Azzurri's withdrawal from reserve grade means for the region's premier competition, which is set to kick off Friday week, is not yet known.
NNSWF general manager of football operations Liam Bentley told the Newcastle Herald that will be finalised next week after consultation with all clubs.
"This situation will create another bye in the reserve-grade competition this season," Bentley said on Monday.
"The NNSWF football operations department will discuss options with clubs at the upcoming standing committee meeting.
"We want to put the options on the table as to whether we try and increase those number of matches, and the impact that has on the rest of that program.
"So we'll talk that through with them and we'll come out with an answer next week.
"It's really disappointing for a flagship competition to not have a full set of reserve grade, but it's a small bump."
Last year, Azzurri won the preseason Charity Shield in February, the League Cup in May, were declared joint winners of the State Cup with Maitland in July, claimed the NPLW first-grade premiership in August then defended their championship crown in September.
Some players retired, along with first-grade coach Heath Whyte, some are not playing this year, and several have joined rival clubs.
Former Matildas player Alicia Ferguson is the club's new NPLW head coach and Premier Youth League Girls technical director.
"We're disappointed we won't have a reserve grade but it presents opportunity for the younger players at our club in the under 17s," Valentinis said.
"When they're called upon, they're going to have to step up to first grade and that will make a better, stronger club for the following year.
"We have really recruited well in first grade. There's a lot of good players coming and it's a pretty new squad.
"With the trial games that we've had, which I've seen first hand, I'm really impressed with the way Alicia has got them playing, so I think we'll definitely be competitive."
MORE SPORT:
Championship-winning goalkeeper Danielle Bartels and defender Chloe Martin remain part of Azzurri's first-grade squad.
New recruits include Sienna Denholm from New Lambton plus experienced NPLW NSW players Rachel Perrins and Erica Di Sciascio.
Azzurri's new-look side face their first test on Friday night against a stacked Maitland Magpies in the preseason Charity Shield at Jack McLaughlan Oval.
Maitland, who were beaten 1-0 by Azzurri in last year's grand final, have lost South African international Marry Ntsweng to Adamstown but have added Elodie Dagg (Newcastle Olympic) and Marion Dunbabin (Adamstown) to their roster under new coach Ben Horgan.
